openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Burundi was valued at $6.75 billion in gross domestic product (GDP) as of the year 2025.
• The economy is heavily dependent on agriculture, which accounted for 32.9% of GDP as of 2008.
• Burundi is a landlocked country characterized by a lack of natural resources and minimal industrialization.
• Agriculture employs more than 70% of the country's labor force, with the majority engaged in subsistence farming.
• Despite having the potential for self-sufficiency in food production, Burundi faces challenges such as civil unrest, overpopulation, and soil erosion.
• These issues have led to a 25% contraction of the subsistence economy in recent years.
• A significant number of internally displaced persons (IDPs) are unable to produce their own food and rely heavily on international humanitarian aid.
• Burundi is a net food importer, with food comprising 17% of its total imports in 1997.
• The country is classified as a least developed country (LDC) by the United Nations.
• In 2022, Burundi produced approximately 2.6 million tons of cassava, making it a significant staple crop for the country.
• The country also produced around 1.3 million tons of bananas in 2022, which are an important food source and export commodity.
• Sweet potato production in 2022 reached approximately 808 thousand tons, contributing to local diets and agriculture.
• Burundi's vegetable output in 2022 was about 507 thousand tons, supporting both domestic consumption and markets.
• The production of beans in 2022 was approximately 499 thousand tons, a key protein source for the population.
• Potatoes were produced at a level of roughly 355 thousand tons in 2022, serving as a vital root crop.
• Maize production in 2022 was about 280 thousand tons, essential for food security and rural livelihoods.
• Sugar cane output reached approximately 188 thousand tons in 2022, supporting local sugar industries.
• Fruit production in 2022 was around 130 thousand tons, encompassing various local fruit varieties.
• Rice production in 2022 was approximately 127 thousand tons, contributing to staple food supplies.
• Taro production in 2022 was about 94 thousand tons, used in traditional dishes and local markets.
• Burundi produced roughly 89 thousand tons of palm oil in 2022, an important edible oil source.
• Tea production in 2022 was around 50 thousand tons, representing a significant export crop.

• Smaller quantities of other agricultural products were produced, including sorghum at 25 thousand tons and coffee at 17 thousand tons, both contributing to the country's agricultural diversity and export potential.
• The industry sector in Burundi is minimal, primarily limited to the processing of agricultural exports.

• Although there are potential natural resources such as petroleum, nickel, copper, and others being explored, the uncertain security situation has deterred significant investor interest in developing these resources.
• Burundi's industrial development faces additional challenges due to its geographic disadvantage of being landlocked, resulting in high transportation costs.
• Lake Tanganyika remains a crucial trading hub for Burundi, serving as an important point for regional commerce.
• The trade embargo imposed on Burundi was lifted in 1999; prior to this, the embargo had a negative impact on the country's trade and industrial sectors.
• Since October 1993, Burundi has experienced extensive ethnic-based violence, resulting in approximately 250,000 deaths and displacing about 800,000 people.
• The country faces shortages in essential supplies, including foods, medicines, and electricity.
• Burundi is heavily reliant on bilateral and multilateral aid; in 1997, its external debt was recorded at $1.247 billion (1.247 G$).

• Starting in July 1986, Burundi implemented a series of largely unsuccessful 5-year plans in partnership with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund aimed at reforming the economy by liberalizing the foreign exchange system, reducing import restrictions, diversifying exports, and reforming the coffee industry.
• Promotion of goat rearing has been undertaken as a strategy to generate income for rural populations.
• IMF structural adjustment programs in Burundi were suspended following the outbreak of the crisis in 1993.

• The World Bank identified key growth areas including improving productivity of traditional crops, introducing new export commodities, developing light manufacturing, industrial mining, and expanding services.
• Major economic challenges include the government's role in the economy, issues of transparency, and the need for debt reduction.

• In 1996, neighboring countries imposed an economic embargo on Burundi to protest the coup led by President Pierre Buyoya; although not officially ratified by the United Nations Security Council, most countries avoided official trade with Burundi.
• Following the coup, the United States suspended all aid except humanitarian assistance.
• The regional embargo was lifted on January 23, 1999, after the Burundian government made progress in national reconciliation through the Burundi peace process.
• According to _Foreign Policy_ in an article titled "The Blood Cries Out," Burundi's population growth rate is 2.5 percent annually, more than double the global average.
• The average number of children per Burundian woman is 6.3, nearly triple the international fertility rate.
• Most Burundians rely on subsistence farming; however, due to rapid population growth and lack of land ownership policies, many have insufficient land to sustain themselves.
• In 2014, the average farm size was approximately one acre.
• The same _Foreign Policy_ article highlighted that Burundi had the highest hunger and malnutrition rates among 120 countries in the 2013 Global Hunger Index.
• Burundi is one of the least electrified countries in the world, with only about 10% of its population having access to electricity.
• In 2022, Burundi produced a total of 565 GWh of electricity.
• Of the total electricity generated in 2022, 50% was produced via fossil fuels, and the remaining 50% was generated through renewable energy sources.
• Oil is the primary fossil fuel used for energy production in Burundi.
• Renewable energy in Burundi is mainly sourced from hydropower, with smaller contributions from solar energy and bioenergy.
• Domestic electricity production in Burundi does not meet the country's demand, leading to significant energy imports from neighboring countries.
• The Rusumo Hydroelectric Power Station, opened in 2023, significantly benefited Burundi by providing 27 MW of electricity.
• The power station, combined with improved transmission infrastructure, enabled Burundi to supply more reliable and consistent power to the capital city, Gitega.
• The opening of Rusumo allowed Burundi to decommission an old oil-fired power station that previously supplied Gitega, saving over two million USD in costs.
• The Rusumo project was part of a broader international aid-assisted initiative aimed at promoting low-carbon electrification and increasing electricity access nationwide.
• The Burundian government is pursuing a major domestic hydropower project at Rubrizi, supported by extensive funding from the African Development Bank and the European Union.
• The Rubrizi hydropower station is scheduled for completion in December 2024 and is designed to generate 160 MW of electricity, making it the largest power station in Burundi.
• Once operational, the Rubrizi power station and related transmission infrastructure improvements are expected to provide electricity access to approximately 7% of Burundi’s population.
• The table presents key economic indicators for Burundi from 1980 to 2024, providing a comprehensive overview of macroeconomic trends over this period.

• In 1980, Burundi's GDP measured 1.54 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 375 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 0.95 billion US dollars; the real GDP growth rate was −6.8%, and the inflation rate was 1.2%, with no available data on government debt.

• Throughout the 1980s, Burundi experienced gradual increases in GDP, reaching 3.33 billion US dollars (PPP) in 1989, with fluctuations in growth and inflation; for example, in 1985, GDP was 2.55 billion US dollars (PPP), with an inflation rate of 11.8%.

• The 1990s saw notable volatility: GDP increased from 3.57 billion US dollars (PPP) in 1990 to a peak of 4.04 billion US dollars (PPP) in 1992, followed by declines during the mid-1990s, with GDP dropping to 3.58 billion US dollars (PPP) in 1995 and further to 3.35 billion US dollars (PPP) in 1996.
• During the 1990s, inflation rates varied significantly, with negative inflation (deflation) observed in 1993 (−6.2%) and 1994 (−3.8%), and high inflation peaks such as 19.2% in 1995.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP remained relatively low in the 1980s but increased notably in the late 1990s, reaching 31.1% in 1997, then fluctuating in subsequent years.

• The early 2000s marked a period of recovery and growth: GDP rose from 4.03 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2001 to 4.66 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2004, with GDP per capita increasing from 585 to 623 US dollars (PPP).

• From 2005 onwards, Burundi experienced steady growth: GDP increased from 5.02 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2005 to 8.80 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2014, with GDP per capita rising from 668 to 888 US dollars (PPP).

• The period 2015–2017 saw a slowdown, with GDP growth rates declining or turning negative; for example, in 2015, GDP was 8.53 billion US dollars (PPP) with a negative growth rate of −3.9%, and in 2016, GDP was 8.56 billion US dollars (PPP) with a slight contraction of −0.6%.

• From 2018 onward, Burundi's economy showed signs of recovery, with GDP reaching 8.94 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2018 and continuing upward to 12.59 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2023, and further to 13.17 billion US dollars (PPP) in 2024.

• The GDP per capita increased from 798 US dollars (PPP) in 2018 to 970 US dollars (PPP) in 2023, and to 986 US dollars (PPP) in 2024, indicating gradual improvements in individual economic well-being.
• Inflation rates fluctuated over the years, with notable periods of low inflation, such as 0.3% in 2020, and higher rates like 4.9% in 2008 and 4.9% in 2013.

• Burundi's government debt as a percentage of GDP varied, reaching a high of 172.7% in 2004, then decreasing to 37.9% in 2013, and rising again to 86.8% in 2024, reflecting changes in fiscal policy and borrowing.

• The data highlights periods of economic instability, recovery, and growth, with key turning points around the early 2000s and post-2015, illustrating Burundi's economic resilience and challenges over the decades.
